big_picture_notes: Jeremiah is a non‑linear anthology of oracles, laments, sign‑acts, and narratives compiled across the prophet’s long ministry. The macro‑structure is modular: large narrative superscriptions mark major collections, while oracle formulas ('The word of the LORD came…', 'Thus says the LORD') are the key scene markers—each scene a single, complete divine speech or report ideal for memorization. The MT places the Oracles Against the Nations at 46–51 (LXX relocates after 25:13), underscoring the book’s editorial history. Thematic glue: relentless covenant lawsuit against Judah, the 'enemy from the north' motif, the prophet’s confessions, and a hope‑center in the Book of Consolation (30–33). Memorize by literary units (oracles), not chronology.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Jeremiah 1 is a distinct proem: formal superscription, first call‑oracle, two commissioning visions (almond branch, boiling pot), and the fortified‑prophet metaphors. Start (1:1): superscription. End (1:19): promise 'I am with you… to deliver you'—inclusio with 1:8. Literary Glue: call dialogue and paired visions leading to charge/promise.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Third‑person editorial frame from Josiah to exile—complete historical title page.
Classic call pattern: divine commission → objection → reassurance → symbolic touch → charge (to pluck up/plant).
Q&A vision with wordplay (shaqed/shoqed: almond/watching) sealing God’s vigilant word.

scenes.scene_name: Vision 2: Boiling Pot and Final Charge
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Vision → interpretation ('from the north') → prophet‑as‑fortress metaphors → closing promise to deliver.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Jeremiah 2–25 is the core pre‑exilic oracle collection: covenant lawsuit, unfaithful wife/vine/cistern metaphors, 'enemy from the north,' temple sermon, confessions, sign‑acts, and the cup of wrath climax. Start (2:1): 'The word of the LORD came…' End (25:38): desolation after the universal cup. Literary Glue: repeated oracle markers and motifs; 25:1–14 functions as hinge/summary of 23 years.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Opening rîb—memory of bridal devotion vs present apostasy; rhetorical close ('Where are they?').
Compact charge ending in the famed summary: forsaken fountain; hewn broken cisterns.
Cause‑effect oracle: foreign ravagers; 'your evil will discipline you'—complete thought.
Sustained harlotry metaphor climaxing in ironic plea to idols: 'Arise and save us!'
Legal disputation—Israel’s protest contra divine verdict; resolves with shaming outcome.

scenes.scene_name: Call to Repentance and Circumcised Hearts
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Twin appeals: return faithless Israel; plough fallow ground; circumcise hearts—paired summons.
Imperatives to sound the trumpet, flee; lion from thicket advances—panic oracle.
Jeremiah’s heart pains; vision of de‑creation chaos—return to tohu va‑bohu motif.
Besiegement instructions; testing/assaying metaphors; complete siege oracle.
Gate speech against false temple confidence—Shiloh precedent—site‑specific sermon unit.
Covenant voice—day I brought them out; stiff neck; truth perished—complete indictment of ritualism.
Crafted idols vs living Creator—mocking taunt; tightly framed polemic.
Oracle recalling Sinai stipulations; 'they did not obey'—root problem stated.
Prophet laments assassination plot; YHWH’s judicial reply—lament‑response unit.
Symbolic act and interpretation—ruined sash equals ruined pride of Judah/Israel.
Clay remade in the potter’s hand—divine sovereignty call to repent—complete sign oracle.
Prose colophon of ministry; nations serve Babylon 70 years; hinge to wider judgment.

scenes.scene_name: Cup of Wrath to the Nations
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Symbolic cup; list of nations; universal desolation—climactic judgment scene.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Jeremiah 26–29 shifts to prose biography: court trial, symbolic yokes, conflict with Hananiah, letters with exiles and Shemaiah. Start (26:1): historical superscription. End (29:32): verdict against Shemaiah. Literary Glue: prose style, dated formulas, true vs false prophecy theme.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Charge → defense → elders’ precedent—single court case narrative.
Sidebar execution of Uriah; Jeremiah protected—compact counterpoint.
Sign‑act yokes; message to kings, priests, people—complete symbolic commission.
Conflict, rebuttal, death oracle, and fulfillment—closed controversy unit.
Epistolary oracle: build, seek shalom; 70 years; warning against false prophets.
Counter‑letter, divine response, and verdict—resolves the letter episode.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Jeremiah 30–33 is a 'book within the book'—explicitly commanded to be written—uniting restoration themes: healing, rebuilding, new covenant, and sign‑act purchase. Start (30:1–2): write in a book. End (33:26): restoration promise. Literary Glue: 'restore the fortunes,' 'my people Israel/Judah,' physical to spiritual renewal arc.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Superscription to the Consolation collection; scope named—Israel and Judah.
Fear oracle resolving in deliverance; restrained judgment ('I will correct you in justice').
Diagnosis → healing promise; Zion called 'outcast' but restored by the Healer.
Restored city and nobility; 'you shall be my people, and I will be your God' refrain.
Lament from Ramah answered by promise of return from enemy land—hope oracle.
Law on hearts, all know the LORD, sins remembered no more—spiritual heart of Consolation.
Narrative sign‑act during siege—pledge that 'houses and fields… shall again be bought.'

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Jeremiah 34–45 resumes prose, tracing final siege, fall, and aftermath in Judah and Egypt, concluding with Baruch’s oracle. Start (34:1): precise siege setting. End (45:5): life as prize of war promise to Baruch. Literary Glue: chronological thread through collapse and remnant’s disobedience.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Word during siege; personal fate of Zedekiah—complete oracle unit.
Manumission made and revoked; covenant broken; judgment announced—narrative oracle.
Obedient clan contrasts Judah’s disobedience; perpetual promise to Rechab’s line.
Baruch writes/reads; king burns; new scroll dictated—complete scroll cycle narrative.
Prophet cast into the pit; Ebed‑melech’s rescue—compact deliverance scene.
Capture and aftermath; Ebed‑melech promised life—wraps siege narrative.
Governor installed → assassination → remnant’s inquiry and disobedience—multi‑part narrative unit.
Sign‑act bricks at Tahpanhes; indictment of queen of heaven worship—judgment on remnant in Egypt.
Personal word—seek not great things; life given as booty—narrative colophon.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Jeremiah 46–51 comprises the international judgment block (Egypt, Philistia, Moab, Ammon, Edom, Damascus, Kedar/Hazor, Elam, and culminates with Babylon). Start (46:1): collection superscription. End (51:64): 'Thus far the words of Jeremiah'—editorial colophon. Literary Glue: nation‑by‑nation judgment sequence with oracle formulas and refrain motifs.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Defeat at the Euphrates; flee, O mighty ones—complete battle oracle.
Nebuchadnezzar strikes Egypt; Israel reassured—paired oracle unit.
Waters rising from the north; sword of the LORD—short nation oracle.
Extensive dirge and taunt with restoration note—long composite oracle.
Rhetorical questions about Milcom; restoration in latter days—compact unit.
Wisdom failed in Teman; eagle soars—complete oracle.
Hamath and Arpad dismayed; palace consumed by fire—short unit.
Plundered nomads; dwell in the deep—brief oracle.
Bow of Elam broken; latter‑day restoration—compact verdict.
Massive anti‑Babylon corpus culminating with scroll sinking at Euphrates—collection capstone with colophon.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Jeremiah 52 is a third‑person historical chronicle paralleling 2 Kings 24:18–25:30, separated by the colophon (51:64). Purpose: confirm fulfillment historically. Start (52:1): regnal formula. End (52:34): Jehoiachin’s daily allowance. Literary Glue: continuous prose narrative of fall, exile, and minor grace note.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Standard regnal rubric ending in rebellion—introductory summary.
Siege account through deportation and remnant—single fall narrative.
Inventory of bronze pillars and vessels—loss catalog scene.
Captives taken and tallied—human cost registry.
Elevation in Babylon—final glimmer closing the book.
